content.statement: proc-002-popliteal-exposure is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Procedures that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding proc-002-popliteal-exposure helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of proc-002-popliteal-exposure include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of proc-002-popliteal-exposure.

definitions_glossary.above_knee_popliteal: The segment of popliteal artery from adductor hiatus to knee joint line
definitions_glossary.below_knee_popliteal: The segment from knee joint to tibioperoneal trunk origin
definitions_glossary.adductor_hiatus: Opening in adductor magnus where femoral vessels become popliteal vessels
definitions_glossary.tibioperoneal_trunk: Branch of popliteal artery giving rise to posterior tibial and peroneal arteries
definitions_glossary.hunters_canal: Subsartorial canal (adductor canal) containing femoral vessels

indications: Tibial artery exposure (extends from BK popliteal)
contraindications: Prior knee surgery with extensive scarring (consider posterior approach)
Active infection in the medial leg (use alternative approach)
Popliteal artery occlusion (may need tibial exposure instead)

positioning.medial_approach: Supine with leg externally rotated, knee slightly flexed with bump under knee
positioning.posterior_approach: Prone with feet hanging off table

steps: Identify and preserve greater saphenous vein if needed for conduit
Incise deep fascia posterior to sartorius
Dissect to find popliteal artery deep to vein
Circumferentially dissect artery and place vessel loop

below_knee_medial.incision: Medial calf, 1-2cm posterior to tibial edge, starting below knee
steps: Divide soleus muscle attachment to tibia

complications.prevention: Identify vein early, know it is superficial to artery
Stay posterior to sartorius at knee
complications.management: Usually numbness to medial ankle, often permanent

complications.prevention: Identify vein early, may need for conduit
complications.management: Ligate if not needed, repair if needed for bypass

complications.prevention: Identify nerve first in posterior approach
complications.management: Motor deficit to plantar flexion, usually recovers

definition.@value: Surgical exposure of the above-knee or below-knee popliteal artery through medial or posterior approach for vascular procedures

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Distinguish between above-knee and below-knee popliteal artery segments
Perform medial approach to the popliteal artery
Identify and protect the popliteal vein, saphenous vein, and saphenous nerve
Understand when posterior approach is indicated
clinical_pearls: The popliteal vein is superficial to the artery - don't dive deep before finding the vein
Flex the knee slightly to relax the posterior structures for easier dissection
The below-knee popliteal requires dividing soleus from tibia to get adequate exposure
Preserve the greater saphenous vein if you might need it for conduit
The posterior approach provides excellent exposure but requires prone positioning

medicalCode.description: Inspection of popliteal artery, open approach
